Gould once said that an organism was not merely a result of a culmination of its genes. (I'm paraphrasing here, as I don't have the exact quote.) In the same vein in The Panda's Thumb, he said body parts are not translated genes...(again don't have the exact quote but I can find that one if someone really wants it.)
 
 So my question is, if he is right, and body parts such as knees, kneecaps, lungs, tongues and eardrums are not translated genes, how did they oginate in the first place? 
 
 Even skin color....look at the following link:
 
 http://in.news.yahoo.com/070108/139/6axgp.html
 
 London, Jan 8 (ANI): People of particular races look different not because of a difference in genes but the same genes being expressed differently.
 
 So is it a surprise to anyone that the distinction of race in humans has no genetic basis? And there can be no darwinist selection if there is no genetic change. There can be no selection if the organism is merely using its genes as tools to express itself.
 
 Likewise with these caterpillars:
 
 http://www.livescience.com/animals/060202_lab_evo.html
 
 The idea was to use similar temperature shocks to evolve a similar change in M. sexta.....Differing color traits induced by environmental factors are called polyphenisms
 .
 Similar differences show up in genetically identical ants, which can develop into queens, soldiers, or workers based on the hormones they're exposed to early in development. Similar hormonal differences can affect the specific color of a butterfly or bird.
 
 Scientists have not understood evolution's exact role in the differences. 
 
 So once again, what we have is a contradiction to darwinism, which says only populations evolve. Instead, we have individuals who have the ability to evolve during development. No change in genes, no selection, no darwinism. Just a re-expression of the same genes during development in response to an environmental cue. These expressions are heritable. 
 
 But the key here is there's no change in genes. Remember, Gould said the organism is not merely a culmination of its genes. And this proves it. But ToE says new body parts show up randomly, just by pure chance:
 
 http://www.nhptv.org/natureworks/nwep1.htm
 
 Adaptations are the result of evolution. Evolution is a change in a species over long periods of time. 
 
 Adaptations usually occur because a gene mutates or changes by accident! Some mutations can help an animal or plant survive better than others in the species without the mutation. 
 
 For example, imagine a bird species. One day a bird is born with a beak that is longer than the beak of other birds in the species. The longer beak helps the bird catch more food. Because the bird can catch more food, it is healthier than the other birds, lives longer and breeds more. The bird passes the gene for a longer beak on to its offspring. They also live longer and have more offspring and the gene continues to be inherited generation after generation. 
 
 The obvious question here is, (outside of a blatant contradiction to Gould) where did this new gene come from? A similar question can be made of a recent post by WW regarding butterflies. New genes don't pop up randomly, accidentally out of magic hats. David Copperfield isn't responsible for biology. But even if a gene could pop up out of thin air for no reason (and from no cause), by Gould's admission, organisms -- and their parts -- are not translated genes.
 
 And remember, the article above says that skin color does not have a genetic basis. Neither did the change in caterpillar color, the sex of ants, or colors of birds or butterflies. So my question is -- can anyone in here show me ANY body part that has a genetic basis....?
 
 And if no body part has a genetic basis -- how did body parts originate and get selected? If body parts are a culmination of multiple genes, then it would take all the genes being in the same place at the same time for that corresponding body part to appear. And obviously it opens up the possbility, if all the genes are not in place to create a whole, fully-functional body part, then we should be seeing organisms/fossils all over the world that have 10%, 20%, or 50% limbs.....not to mention partial organs.
 
 So the main question here is: do specific body parts correlate to specific genes. If not, then please explain yourself.

So the main question here is: do specific body parts correlate to specific genes. If not, then please explain yourself.

 
 This is, in fact, a very straightforward question. The answer is, of course, no. To understand the answer, however, requires a least a basic understanding of genetics, which you lack. I would strongly recommend you find any college level introductory text to genetics and read it. Doing so might prevent you from making so many "here's something I don't understand so evolution is wrong" posts.

Oh, I see....so I ask a straight-forward question but I'm too dumb to have it explained to me. Why is it that darwinian evidence is always somewhere else -- somewhere we can't quite see it? Do you have any titles of these books I should be looking for? And do you own them? I'd like to ask a few questions about them and maybe get you to give me a couple quotes. 
 
 Fact is, I have several evolutionists' books and I have yet to see an explanation of what I have asked for. Why don't you suck it up and tell me?

Oh, I see....so I ask a straight-forward question but I'm too dumb to have it explained to me. 

 I really have no idea how dumb you are. I do know that every time somehow has tried to explain basic genetics to you you've resisted with all your might. If you really want to learn this stuff the info is out there. Since you clearly haven't tried, you clearly don't really want to know. I have no real interest in trying to force you to learn something you don't actually want to know.
 
 

 Fact is, I have several evolutionists' books and I have yet to see an explanation of what I have asked for. Why don't you suck it up and tell me?

 "Evolutionists' books", eh? And are any of them actual genetics textbooks? Because that's what your question is about.
Are bodies JUST translated body parts?

Are genes parts of the body?
 
 If genes are NOT body parts what are they?

I really have no idea how dumb you are. I do know that every time somehow has tried to explain basic genetics to you you've resisted with all your might. If you really want to learn this stuff the info is out there. Since you clearly haven't tried, you clearly don't really want to know. I have no real interest in trying to force you to learn something you don't actually want to know.
 
 
 "Evolutionists' books", eh? And are any of them actual genetics textbooks? Because that's what your question is about.

 
 
 answer my questions. Here they are again:
 
 Do you have any titles of these books I should be looking for? And do you own them? I'd like to ask a few questions about them and maybe get you to give me a couple quotes. 
 
 Fact is, I have several evolutionists' books and I have yet to see an explanation of what I have asked for. Why don't you suck it up and tell me?
 
 If you're going to open your mouth then I'm going to make you back yourself up. So let's hear it.

So the main question here is: do specific body parts correlate to specific genes. 

 
 Yes most certainly and necessarily if genes are body parts. If genes are not parts of the body then maybe not. Depends!
You can now answer your own question.

If you're going to open your mouth then I'm going to make you back yourself up. So let's hear it.

 
 Your question is answerable with only the basic knowledge of biochemistry found in any highschool text. Among the parts of the human body there are chemical suststances called genes. Genes are body parts. Genes correlate to themselves very well

Yes most certainly and necessarily if genes are body parts. If genes are not parts of the body then maybe not. Depends!

 
 lol....you call that science?

Your question is answerable with only the basic knowledge of biochemistry found in any highschool text. Among the parts of the human body there are chemical suststances called genes. Genes are body parts. Genes correlate to themselves very well

 
 Answer my question? Ok.....the study of genes is a complete and total waste of time because not only do genes not translate to body parts, but their actions are not the true cause of evolutionary change. Evolutionists have made a living ignoring causes. But the game's over now.

Answer my question? Ok.....the study of genes is a complete and total waste of time because not only do genes not translate to body parts, but their actions are not the true cause of evolutionary change. Evolutionists have made a living ignoring causes. But the game's over now.

 
 So you are of the opinion that genes are not parts of your body? Do I have that correct? What else could they be? I mean after all a great deal of the structure of a bacterium consists of its genes! At that level genes are body parts and vital ones at that. Of course there are other body parts like enzymes etc, but we know that enzymes at least are to a very large degree translations of genes.
 
 Your problem is that you have failed to understand that life is modular and elaborational in its deep modularity. Hard to see how even an amateur thinker could make such an error of composition.

Answer my question?

 
 Your question was whether genes translate to body parts. Genes are body parts and become structurally elaborated to make other body parts. Provided that you consider genes to be body parts in the first place. If you don't you could at least tell us what category genes actaully fall into!

So you are of the opinion that genes are not parts of your body? Do I have that correct? What else could they be? I mean after all a great deal of the structure of a bacterium consists of its genes! At that level genes are body parts and vital ones at that. Of course there are other body parts like enzymes etc, but we know that enzymes at least are to a very large degree translations of genes.
 
 Your problem is that you have failed to understand that life is modular and elaborational in its deep modularity. Hard to see how even an amateur thinker could make such an error of composition.

 
 quit playing around, chemist. You know what I mean. Evolutionists have claimed for decades that humans have built up one gene at a time, transforming us from some supposedly genetically-simple microorganism floating in a swamp to the complex being we are now. This implies that the buildup of genes correlates with the array of different anatomical parts we see in ourselves and in other animals. But it sorta pulls the rug out from under this whole concept if physical structures are not linked to specific genes. Evos have tried to figure out where new genes come from, but what does it matter if they do not correlate to body parts?

answer my questions. Here they are again:
 
 Do you have any titles of these books I should be looking for? And do you own them? I'd like to ask a few questions about them and maybe get you to give me a couple quotes. 
 
 Fact is, I have several evolutionists' books and I have yet to see an explanation of what I have asked for. Why don't you suck it up and tell me?
 
 If you're going to open your mouth then I'm going to make you back yourself up. So let's hear it.

 
 No, SS. I've made it quite clear I have no intention of pandering to your ignorance which you hold so dear. pandion has answered all your questions before in rigorous detail, and you've ignored his answers. I feel no need to join that club. If the day ever comes when you don't feel the need to protect your ignorance, if you ever trully wish to expand your horizons and actually learn, then go out and get a genentics book as I recommended. Till then I see no reason for me to engage in a lengthy explanation which you won't even read. I'm sure you'll twist this in your mind to indicate something profound, but then I really can't be held responsible for whatever goes on in that skull of yours, so I can't worry myself about it too much.

Fact is, I have several evolutionists' books and I have yet to see an explanation of what I have asked for. 

 
 1) After you purchase the books you need to read them.
 
 2) And you probably can find something closer to what you are looking for in the Sci-Fi literature in the first place.

Sport TOTALLY misinterpreted and misrepresented the links he provides. 
 
 Make that - he totally misinterpreted /misrepresented the articles that he is busily spamming multiple boards with now...
 
 ==============================================
 
Quote:
 Originally Posted by supersport 
 I just love exposing the myth of darwinism. Just yesterday a guy came on here and made a post about how he couldn't believe in creation because creationists had no explanation for the races. I told him that the emergence of different races had absolutely nothing to do with darwinism because skin color is not genetic. Instead, skin color is an epigenetic trait, and as a corrolation, I even showed him a link how green caterpillars can turn black when exposed to heat during development. Here it is:
 
 http://www.livescience.com/animals/060202_lab_evo.html
 
 The idea was to use similar temperature shocks to evolve a similar change in M. sexta.....Differing color traits induced by environmental factors are called polyphenisms
 .
 Similar differences show up in genetically identical ants, which can develop into queens, soldiers, or workers based on the hormones they're exposed to early in development. Similar hormonal differences can affect the specific color of a butterfly or bird.
 
 Scientists have not understood evolution's exact role in the differences. lol!
 
 So what we have in the above experiment is a contradiction to darwinism, which says only populations evolve. Instead, we have individuals who have the ability to evolve during development. 

 
 Color change in response to developmental differences in temperature is not evolution. Strawman.

 Quote:
 
 No change in genes, no selection, no darwinism. Just a re-expression of the same genes during development in response to an environmental cue. These expressions are obviously heritable. 

 
 It is amazing what you can find out when you look beyond a dumbed-down internet news article. This is the paper alluded to in the linked story:
 
 =====================================Science. 2006 Feb 3;311(5761):650-2.
 
 Evolution of a polyphenism by genetic accommodation.
 Suzuki Y, Nijhout HF.
 Department of Biology, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, USA. ys16@duke.edu
 
 Polyphenisms are adaptations in which a genome is associated with discrete alternative phenotypes in different environments. Little is known about the mechanism by which polyphenisms originate. We show that a mutation in the juvenile hormone-regulatory pathway in Manduca sexta enables heat stress to reveal a hidden reaction norm of larval coloration. Selection for increased color change in response to heat stress resulted in the evolution of a larval color polyphenism and a corresponding change in hormonal titers through genetic accommodation. Evidently, mechanisms that regulate developmental hormones can mask genetic variation and act as evolutionary capacitors, facilitating the origin of novel adaptive phenotypes.=======================================
 
 And what was it Supersport wrote?
 
 Ah, yes:
 
 "No change in genes, no selection, no darwinism"
 
 

 Quote:
 So is it any surprise that we also see that races of humans have no genetic basis? Of course not! 
 
 http://in.news.yahoo.com/070108/139/6axgp.html
 
 London, Jan 8 (ANI): People of particular races look different not because of a difference in genes but the same genes being expressed differently. (ie..no selectionist darwinism again.)
 
 So at this point, only a complete atheist/activist ideologue could maintain that the different races of humans evolved via darwinian selection. If a caterpillar can turn black due to an increase of temperature during development, then there is absolutely no reason to believe that humans can't do the same thing. And again, the effects are heritable. And if different races/different pigmentations don't arise as a result of selection, why should we believe any other biological trait does?
 
 Darwinism is scientifically worthless and it needs to be flushed.
 
 edit:.....the article says that skin color does not have a genetic basis. So my question is -- can anyone in here show me ANY body part that has a genetic basis....? 

 
 The very title of the article shows that you are being dishonest/incompetent in your 'reporting':
 
 Same genes expressed differently behind races looking different
 
 
 Genes being expressed differently is NOT a genetic basis?
 
 Of course, again, we see something different when we look at the actual paper:
 
 =============================================Nat Genet. 2007 Feb;39(2):226-31. Epub 2007 Jan 7.
 Common genetic variants account for differences in gene expression among ethnic groups.
 Spielman RS, Bastone LA, Burdick JT, Morley M, Ewens WJ, Cheung VG.
 Department of Genetics, University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19104, USA. spielman@pobox.upenn.edu
 
 Variation in DNA sequence contributes to individual differences in quantitative traits, but in humans the specific sequence variants are known for very few traits. We characterized variation in gene expression in cells from individuals belonging to three major population groups. This quantitative phenotype differs significantly between European-derived and Asian-derived populations for 1,097 of 4,197 genes tested. For the phenotypes with the strongest evidence of cis determinants, most of the variation is due to allele frequency differences at cis-linked regulators. The results show that specific genetic variation among populations contributes appreciably to differences in gene expression phenotypes. Populations differ in prevalence of many complex genetic diseases, such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease. As some of these are probably influenced by the level of gene expression, our results suggest that allele frequency differences at regulatory polymorphisms also account for some population differences in prevalence of complex diseases.==================================
 What is an allele, Sport? And what does frequency difference mean to you?
 
 This was a particularly poor showing by you, Sport. Your hyperbolic thread title seems especially pathetic in light of the fact that, yet again, your "interpretation" of news releases (the second of which, sadly, was so poorly written that I can almost see how you misinterpreted what was written) was so comically inept that this thread can really only act to embarrass the YECs on this board.

 
 Sport then, of course, went on a tangent-fest attempting to justify and support his misinterpretation and failed miserably, but, of cours,e that is beyond his ability to realize.

derwood, by the way, why do you go by "derwood" at Carm and other forums such as EvC, yet SLP here?
 
 I'm sorry, but even though there may have been a mutation involved, there is still nothing darwinian about this experiment. Darwin says that creatures are fit because they happen to be born by fit parents or they happen to be a one-in-a-billion lucky mutant. This is neither of these. These caterpillars are creating their own fitness during development. I don't know why you think just because a mutation may have been involved that it somehow validates darwinism. Granted I did not dig into the paper like you did, thus I did not realize there was a mutation, but the mutation could not have been a random event. Also the selection actually had an IQ behind it...ie..scientists picking and choosing which caterpillars they wanted...this is not the same as natural selection.
 
 But just so I am understanding this correctly, did these scientists observe this mutation or are they just assuming one happened, which lead to the ability to do what they did.

These caterpillars are creating their own fitness during development. 

 
 Ah yes. Is this before or after they emerge from the butterfly wombs?

derwood, by the way, why do you go by "derwood" at Carm and other forums such as EvC, yet SLP here?

 I forgot my registration info at CARM and had to re-register, and since there was already an 'SLP' in their database, I couldn't use that name. Basically the same at EvC.

 
 I'm sorry, but even though there may have been a mutation involved,

 Ah, so you FINALLY admit you were wrong. That is the first step!

 
 there is still nothing darwinian about this experiment. 

 No, there was nothing darwinian intended by the experiment. Didn't you even read the article YOU linked to?
Darwin says that creatures are fit because they happen to be born by fit parents or they happen to be a one-in-a-billion lucky mutant. This is neither of these. 

 See, now I KNOW you didn't even read the article YOU linked to!
 
 From it:
 
 "None of this looks to be going anywhere in the sense of survival of the fittest. The black and green caterpillars will all grow up basically the same."

 
 These caterpillars are creating their own fitness during development.

 
 Try again:
 
 
 ""The adult moths are identical, and so there is no obvious basis for the kind of selective mating that might genetically isolate two groups and eventually lead to new species," Nijhout told LiveScience. Because the variations are based on temperatures, and thus in the wild would be dependent on seasons, the two types would tend to occur at different times of the year and may never meet in nature, he said."
 
 
 Has nothing to do with fitness.
 
 Coupling not reading your own links with strawman fallacies - good one!

 
 I don't know why you think just because a mutation may have been involved that it somehow validates darwinism. 

 I never said it did. My whole enterprise on this subject was to, once again, demonstrate that you were wrong on nearly every subject your decided to write about on this topic - so much so that you coul dnot even comprehend (or ignored) much of what the very thing YOU linked to contained!

 
 Granted I did not dig into the paper like you did, thus I did not realize there was a mutation, 

 
 Dig in? I did not realize that a 3 minute internet search and 2-3 minutes of skimming the actual paper would be considered 'digging in' - but you bring up a good point. The internet creationist skims articles, performs keyword searches, reads a few creationist online articles and fancies himself na expert. The evolutionist actully 'digs into' the material and actually tries to understand it and in doing so, more often than not, can falsify the creationists' claims and even embarrass them by pointing out that they did not even understand - perhaps even read - the things they linked to!

 
 but the mutation could not have been a random event. 

 
 Why not? You yammer on about scientists 'guessing' about things, and here you are making a silly totally evidence-less assertion as if it were a fact!

 Also the selection actually had an IQ behind it...ie..scientists picking and choosing which caterpillars they wanted...this is not the same as natural selection.

 
 More evidence that you cannot understand even dumbed-down internet articles. Try reading it again - or more liklley, for the first time. Oh, right - you don't have time...

 
 But just so I am understanding this correctly, did these scientists observe this mutation or are they just assuming one happened, which lead to the ability to do what they did.

 
 Please read what I wrote to you on CARM, I don't have to time to explain it all again.

Derwood/SLP: The experiment involved did not produce a new mutation, it unmasked the old one. You see? 
 
 Yes I see -- and it's just as I said...the mutation part was a guess based on Fred's worldview. It's no different than Richard Dawkins blindly claiming that millions of copying errors built up animals gradually over millions of years. It's a guess -- and a non-evidence-based guess at that. I could do the same thing by saying God formed this ability with a bolt of lightning. What's the difference? Neither is science.
 
 The rest of the experiment, the acutal biological reality, has nothing to do with darwinism...in fact, it's anti-darwin. Sorry, you sure wasted alot of time and effort for nothing.
 
 By the way, I've been very busy today...my wife's been dragging me back and forth to relatives' houses. So even a 3-minute "dig" is more than I can manage at the moment.

 The rest of the experiment, the acutal biological reality, has nothing to do with darwinism...in fact, it's anti-darwin. Sorry, you sure wasted alot of time and effort for nothing.
